awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Injectable Biomimetic Scaffolds to Direct  Stem Cell-Derived Cardiomyocyte Differentiation
awd_abstract_narration:
1150854/ Lipke

The PI's long-term research goal is to develop a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms by which biomimetic materials can drive electrophysiological maturation of stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes (SC-CMs). This CAREER research plan uses a novel hydrogel microsphere encapsulation system to provide pluripotent stem cells with specific cues to direct their differentiation into cardiomyocytes and assesses the functional electrophysiological properties of resulting SC-CMs at the single cell and tissue levels. Using current differentiation methods, SC-CM maturation typically does not progress beyond a prenatal phenotype and overall electrophysiological properties vary greatly. Therefore, the objective of the PI?s research plan is to test the following hypotheses: (1) biomimetic scaffolds can be used to increase the homogeneity of SC-CMs and decrease variability in electrophysiological properties both within and between differentiation batches; (2) localized release of signaling molecules, including nitric oxide, can be used to enhance SC-CM maturity; (3) electrophysiological properties of SC-CMs will depend on the differentiation environment they are provided including variations in copolymer formulation, culture time, and initial stem cell concentration; and (4) SC-CMs will enhance electrical propagation through engineered cardiac tissues by directly coupling with more mature neonatal ventricular-derived cardiomyocytes. The following educational goals are integrated with the PI's research objective: (1) maintain a 1:1 ratio of undergraduate to graduate student researchers in her laboratory; (2) engage cardiac nursing students in learning about stem cell and cardiac regeneration research so they are better prepared to educate patients; (3) incorporate cardiovascular research-related content and projects into her coursework; (4) inspire K-12 students to pursue science and engineering careers through conducting K-12 outreach (5) support women and minority retention in science and engineering through organizational activities and one-on-one mentoring.

Intellectual Merit: The PI's focus on characterizing and directing SC-CM electrophysiology is unique, particularly for SC-CMs differentiated in scalable systems or encapsulated in biomaterial scaffolds, and the anticipated results will provide a valuable foundation for others in the field. Knowledge gained from these studies will be applied to the design of injectable biomaterial scaffolds and engineered cardiac tissues to improve electrophysiological integration, which is essential for cardiac regeneration. Establishing a fundamental understanding of how to uniformly progress SC-CM electrophysiological maturity and using this information to develop differentiation systems that control batch-to-batch variability is critical to reducing SC-CM's potential to cause deadly arrhythmias. In addition, obtaining sufficient numbers of homogeneous cells to form tissues is challenging. The interdisciplinary nature of this research draws on and furthers our knowledge of fundamentals in several fields including transport phenomena and thermodynamics, electrical signal processing, and developmental biology.

Broader Impacts: Heart disease is the number one cause of death in the United States each year for both men and women. Improving the ability to repair damaged or diseased hearts will provide patients the opportunity for both a longer and potentially better quality of life. The results of the PI's research will provide the foundation for educational materials that will be integrated into her core undergraduate courses and upper level cell and tissue engineering course. Cardiac nursing students, who in their careers will be important health educators, will also come to the PI's lab to learn about stem cell and cardiac regeneration research. Mentoring undergraduate researchers will continue to be a priority the PI, and she will expand her efforts to engage students from underrepresented groups. To engage K-12 students in this research and foster their interest in pursuing a career in science and engineering, the PI will use existing, successful frameworks including Auburn University's Youth Experience in Science (YES) camps and Getting Under the Surface (GUTS) program.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overarching long-term goal of this research is to develop an understanding of the capacity of biomimetic materials to support cardiac differentiation of pluripotent stem cells and learn how material properties can be modulated to drive subsequent maturation of resulting contracting heart cells, or cardiomyocytes, and cardiac tissues. Following a myocardial infarction, over one billion cells are permanently lost. Current therapies are unable to regenerate the damaged heart muscle, leading to eventual heart failure. Although pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes have the potential to be used for cardiac regeneration, without systems for producing the large numbers of cells needed and directing their electrophysiological maturation, employing these cells for regenerative therapies is not a viable clinical option. Through this project Dr. Lipke’s lab provided new knowledge and systems for moving towards this goals. 

This project generated the following outcomes. Dr. Lipke and her research team established the ability encapsulate first mouse and then human induced pluripotent stem cells within photocrosslinkable hydrogels and differentiate the cells to directly produce 3D engineered cardiac tissues(Kerscher et al., 2016) (Kerscher et al., 2017). This method eliminates a number of cumbersome steps in the typical process of forming engineered cardiac tissues, which is critical for being able to move towards clinical use. Using their 3D engineered cardiac tissue differentiation, Dr. Lipke and her research group were the first to report the observation of T-tubules in cardiomyocytes derived from human pluripotent stem cells (Kerscher et al., 2016). This result was unexpected and two patents have been issued. Achieving maturation of stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes has been an elusive goal for the field.

Fundamental knowledge of how biomimetic materials can be used to drive electrophysiological maturation stem cell derived-cardiomyocytes will be instrumental to the field’s advancement. In this project, Dr. Lipke and her research team tested multiple types of materials. They showed that addition of a soluble nitric oxide donor results in enhanced electrophysiological maturation of mouse PSC-derived cardiomyocytes differentiating in suspension (Hodge et al., 2016). In addition, the Lipke Lab demonstrated that culturing cardiac cells on conductive polymer films, mimicking the conductive nature of heart tissue, also encourages electrophysiological development (Spearman et al., 2015). 

In this project Dr. Lipke and her research group established multiple novel systems for engineered tissue microsphere production (Pradhan et al., 2014) (Pradhan et al., 2017), including most recently a unique microfluidic platform that rapidly encapsulates mammalian cells in hydrogel microspheres at much faster rates and higher cell densities than previously achieved (Seeto et al., 2017) (Seeto et al.,2019). From bioreactor cell production to injectable cell therapy, spheroidal tissues are highly advantageous; the microfluidic cell encapsulation platform established in this project overcomes production critical barriers to employing cell-laden microspheres for downstream commercial applications; a patent application has been submitted. In addition to use in supporting 3D suspension-based cardiac differentiation of human pluripotent stem cells, these microspheres were also employed for use in injectable therapeutic cell delivery (Seeto et al., 2017).

In addition to the primary research results, book chapters (Hodge et al., 2014) (Trosper et al., 2014) and review articles (Dunn et al., 2013) were written to compile and examine existing knowledge on biomimetic materials design for cardiac tissue regeneration. A methods chapter was also written to disseminate methods established to characterize mitochondrial populations during stem cell differentiation (Kerscher et al., 2015). Finally, outcomes of this project were highlighted as an invited full-length article in Chemical Engineering Progress (Ellis & Lipke, 2018). This research project uniquely focused on characterizing and directing stem cell-derived cardiomyocyte function, specifically electrophysiological function, using scalable differentiation systems and encapsulation of cells in hydrogel scaffolds; the generated research results provide a valuable foundation for others in the field of cardiac regeneration.

This project also accomplished objectives related to engaging students in learning about science and engineering and increasing participation by members of underrepresented groups. Based on multiple sources, including the National Academy of Engineering, involving more K-12 students in science and engineering is a national priority. During this project students from high school to elementary school were regularly engaged through activities led by Dr. Lipke and her students. In addition to local outreach, Dr. Lipke organized one of the two activities in AIChE’s “Chemical Engineering: Mixing it up with polymers” booth for the 2014 USA Science & Engineering Festival in Washington, which had approximately 300,000 attendees over a three day period. As a leader in the AIChE National Women’s Initiative Committee (WIC), Dr. Lipke coordinated workshops during the 2012 and 2013 AIChE Annual Meetings for undergraduate, graduate and junior faculty women, providing important career development tools and helping them build stronger networks, which is critical to their retention. The need to diversify the pipeline for science and engineering professionals has been recognized as a national priority and is a key part of the American competitiveness and other government initiatives.


Last Modified: 09/03/2019
Modified by: Elizabeth Lipke
